repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Use actual Tree-sitter query syntax for the inspector window. This makes parsing with the query parser work correctly and more reliably.

In particular this means that nested nodes are grouped within parentheses (like all lisps).

comment_regular_data.body:
Sample to see what it looks like:

```lisp
(comment) ; [1:1 - 51]
(preproc_ifdef ; [2:1 - 6:6]
  name: (identifier) ; [2:8 - 12]
  (preproc_def ; [3:1 - 4:0]
    name: (identifier) ; [3:10 - 15]
    value: (preproc_arg)) ; [3:17 - 37]
  alternative: (preproc_else ; [4:1 - 6:0]
    (preproc_def ; [5:1 - 6:0]
      name: (identifier))) ; [5:10 - 15]
(preproc_include ; [7:1 - 8:0]
  path: (system_lib_string)) ; [7:10 - 19]
(preproc_include ; [8:1 - 9:0]
  path: (system_lib_string)) ; [8:10 - 19]
(preproc_include ; [9:1 - 10:0]
  path: (system_lib_string)) ; [9:10 - 25]
(preproc_include ; [10:1 - 11:0]
  path: (system_lib_string)) ; [10:10 - 20]
(preproc_include ; [11:1 - 12:0]
  path: (system_lib_string)) ; [11:10 - 19]
(preproc_include ; [12:1 - 13:0]
  path: (system_lib_string)) ; [12:10 - 18]
(preproc_include ; [13:1 - 14:0]
  path: (system_lib_string)) ; [13:10 - 19]
(preproc_include ; [14:1 - 15:0]
  path: (system_lib_string)) ; [14:10 - 19]
(preproc_ifdef ; [15:1 - 18:6]
  name: (identifier) ; [15:8 - 24]
  (preproc_include ; [16:1 - 17:0]
    path: (system_lib_string)) ; [16:11 - 38]
  (preproc_include ; [17:1 - 18:0]
    path: (system_lib_string)) ; [17:11 - 39]
(comment) ; [20:1 - 17]
(preproc_include ; [21:1 - 22:0]
  path: (string_literal ; [21:10 - 21]
    (string_content) ; [21:11 - 20]
(comment) ; [22:1 - 16]
(preproc_include ; [24:1 - 25:0]
  path: (string_literal ; [24:10 - 24]
    (string_content) ; [24:11 - 23]
  (comment)) ; [24:27 - 46]
(preproc_include ; [25:1 - 26:0]
  path: (string_literal ; [25:10 - 29]
    (string_content) ; [25:11 - 28]
(preproc_include ; [26:1 - 27:0]
  path: (string_literal ; [26:10 - 34]
    (string_content) ; [26:11 - 33]
(preproc_include ; [27:1 - 28:0]
  path: (string_literal ; [27:10 - 37]
    (string_content) ; [27:11 - 36]
(preproc_include ; [28:1 - 29:0]
  path: (string_literal ; [28:10 - 24]
    (string_content) ; [28:11 - 23]
(preproc_include ; [29:1 - 30:0]
  path: (string_literal ; [29:10 - 25]
    (string_content) ; [29:11 - 24]
(preproc_include ; [30:1 - 31:0]
  path: (string_literal ; [30:10 - 23]
    (string_content) ; [30:11 - 22]
(preproc_include ; [31:1 - 32:0]
  path: (string_literal ; [31:10 - 25]
    (string_content) ; [31:11 - 24]
(preproc_include ; [32:1 - 33:0]
  path: (string_literal ; [32:10 - 24]
    (string_content) ; [32:11 - 23]
(preproc_include ; [33:1 - 34:0]
```
Another nice feature of this is that it enables jumping to the end of a node using the standard `%` key to jump between open and closing parens.
Hmm, one significant(?) advantage is that you can now copy&paste from the Treeview to the Query Editor.

> Sample to see what it looks like:

How does it look if you show the anonymous nodes?
Hmm it's not quite 100% correct yet -- moving to draft.

> > Sample to see what it looks like:
> 
> How does it look if you show the anonymous nodes?

```lisp
local_declaration: (variable_declaration ; [1:1 - 24]
  "local" ; [1:1 - 5]
  (assignment_statement ; [1:7 - 24]
    (variable_list ; [1:7 - 7]
      name: (identifier)) ; [1:7 - 7]
    "=" ; [1:9 - 9]
    (expression_list ; [1:11 - 24]
      value: (table_constructor ; [1:11 - 24]
        "{" ; [1:11 - 11]
        (field ; [1:12 - 16]
          name: (identifier) ; [1:12 - 12]
          "=" ; [1:14 - 14]
          value: (number)) ; [1:16 - 16]
        "," ; [1:17 - 17]
        (field ; [1:19 - 23]
          name: (identifier) ; [1:19 - 19]
          "=" ; [1:21 - 21]
          value: (number)) ; [1:23 - 23]
        "}")))) ; [1:24 - 24]
(function_call ; [3:1 - 12]
  name: (identifier) ; [3:1 - 5]
  arguments: (arguments ; [3:6 - 12]
    "(" ; [3:6 - 6]
    (bracket_index_expression ; [3:7 - 11]
      table: (identifier) ; [3:7 - 7]
      "[" ; [3:8 - 8]
      field: (unary_expression ; [3:9 - 10]
        "#" ; [3:9 - 9]
        operand: (identifier)) ; [3:10 - 10]
      "]") ; [3:11 - 11]
    ")")) ; [3:12 - 12]
```

This PR changes the indent from 1 space to 2 spaces as well. For a better before and after, here are the changes with only 1 space:

**Before**:

```lisp
local_declaration: (variable_declaration) ; [1:1 - 24]
 "local" ; [1:1 - 5]
 (assignment_statement) ; [1:7 - 24]
  (variable_list) ; [1:7 - 7]
   name: (identifier) ; [1:7 - 7]
  "=" ; [1:9 - 9]
  (expression_list) ; [1:11 - 24]
   value: (table_constructor) ; [1:11 - 24]
    "{" ; [1:11 - 11]
    (field) ; [1:12 - 16]
     name: (identifier) ; [1:12 - 12]
     "=" ; [1:14 - 14]
     value: (number) ; [1:16 - 16]
    "," ; [1:17 - 17]
    (field) ; [1:19 - 23]
     name: (identifier) ; [1:19 - 19]
     "=" ; [1:21 - 21]
     value: (number) ; [1:23 - 23]
    "}" ; [1:24 - 24]
(function_call) ; [3:1 - 12]
 name: (identifier) ; [3:1 - 5]
 arguments: (arguments) ; [3:6 - 12]
  "(" ; [3:6 - 6]
  (bracket_index_expression) ; [3:7 - 11]
   table: (identifier) ; [3:7 - 7]
   "[" ; [3:8 - 8]
   field: (unary_expression) ; [3:9 - 10]
    "#" ; [3:9 - 9]
    operand: (identifier) ; [3:10 - 10]
   "]" ; [3:11 - 11]
  ")" ; [3:12 - 12]
```

**After**:

```lisp
local_declaration: (variable_declaration ; [1:1 - 24]
 "local" ; [1:1 - 5]
 (assignment_statement ; [1:7 - 24]
  (variable_list ; [1:7 - 7]
   name: (identifier)) ; [1:7 - 7]
  "=" ; [1:9 - 9]
  (expression_list ; [1:11 - 24]
   value: (table_constructor ; [1:11 - 24]
    "{" ; [1:11 - 11]
    (field ; [1:12 - 16]
     name: (identifier) ; [1:12 - 12]
     "=" ; [1:14 - 14]
     value: (number)) ; [1:16 - 16]
    "," ; [1:17 - 17]
    (field ; [1:19 - 23]
     name: (identifier) ; [1:19 - 19]
     "=" ; [1:21 - 21]
     value: (number)) ; [1:23 - 23]
    "}")))) ; [1:24 - 24]
(function_call ; [3:1 - 12]
 name: (identifier) ; [3:1 - 5]
 arguments: (arguments ; [3:6 - 12]
  "(" ; [3:6 - 6]
  (bracket_index_expression ; [3:7 - 11]
   table: (identifier) ; [3:7 - 7]
   "[" ; [3:8 - 8]
   field: (unary_expression ; [3:9 - 10]
    "#" ; [3:9 - 9]
    operand: (identifier)) ; [3:10 - 10]
   "]") ; [3:11 - 11]
  ")")) ; [3:12 - 12]
```
I think this will only be noticeable with deep nesting -- where this probably _does_ make a difference; with 20 indents or so, doubling adds up (hah!)

In my opinion both are equally readable (or unreadable, if you have a Lisp allergy). So the benefits of this change are:

1. Being able to more easily jump between start and end node positions with `%`
2. Being able to copy text into the query editor
3. Using the `query` filetype and `query` TS parser

> I think this will only be noticeable with deep nesting -- where this probably _does_ make a difference; with 20 indents or so, doubling adds up (hah!)

We can leave it at 1 space indents if people prefer that. I don't feel strongly about it.

> ```lisp
> local_declaration: (variable_declaration ; [1:1 - 24]
>   "local" ; [1:1 - 5]
>   (assignment_statement ; [1:7 - 24]
>     (variable_list ; [1:7 - 7]
>       name: (identifier)) ; [1:7 - 7]
>     "=" ; [1:9 - 9]
>     (expression_list ; [1:11 - 24]
>       value: (table_constructor ; [1:11 - 24]
>         "{" ; [1:11 - 11]
>         (field ; [1:12 - 16]
>           name: (identifier) ; [1:12 - 12]
>           "=" ; [1:14 - 14]
>           value: (number)) ; [1:16 - 16]
>         "," ; [1:17 - 17]
>         (field ; [1:19 - 23]
>           name: (identifier) ; [1:19 - 19]
>           "=" ; [1:21 - 21]
>           value: (number)) ; [1:23 - 23]
>         "}")))) ; [1:24 - 24]
> (function_call ; [3:1 - 12]
>   name: (identifier) ; [3:1 - 5]
>   arguments: (arguments ; [3:6 - 12]
>     "(" ; [3:6 - 6]
>     (bracket_index_expression ; [3:7 - 11]
>       table: (identifier) ; [3:7 - 7]
>       "[" ; [3:8 - 8]
>       field: (unary_expression ; [3:9 - 10]
>         "#" ; [3:9 - 9]
>         operand: (identifier)) ; [3:10 - 10]
>       "]") ; [3:11 - 11]
>     ")")) ; [3:12 - 12]
> ```

That looks good to me. As a less important side question: Is there something we could set to make it easy to identify whether the `query` file I am highlighting is `InspectTree` or a normal `query` file? Or is there already something I could easily catch that I missed?

> We can leave it at 1 space indents if people prefer that. I don't feel strongly about it.

Me neither; for small nesting a slight preference for 2 on principle. Otherwise I agree that the benefits are significant enough to switch.

> Or is there already something I could easily catch that I missed?

Are the line annotations not obvious enough?

>As a less important side question: Is there something we could set to make it easy to identify whether the query file I am highlighting is InspectTree or a normal query file?

Do you mean programmatically? The inspector sets the `b:dev_base` buffer variable, though that's not documented or part of the API so use with caution.

> Are the line annotations not obvious enough?

I am not sure if I understand exactly what you mean?

I meant something along the lines of a buffer option. Currently I assume I am looking at the `InspectTree` if `vim.bo.buftype == 'nofile'` and a normal `query` file otherwise. But this doesn't work perfectly (e.g. the query editor in the "playground" is also 'nofile'). I could specify more of the buffer options for the `InspectTree`, but I was wondering if there was an easier way that I am missing? And if not, if there was an easy thing to add to simplify this?

Note: This is not very important, and I don't think it needs to be part of this pull request. 

Update: @gpanders: Thank you, `vim.b.dev_base` seems to work for me as I wanted.
What is the actual problem here? Maybe better to describe this in a followup issue.

> What is the actual problem here? Maybe better to describe this in a followup issue.

I think @gpanders comment on using `vim.b.dev_base` solves my problem, so we don't need to change anything. At most we could add a comment to the docs that you can use `vim.b.dev_base` to detect whether you are in `InspectTree`.
But, again, why would you want to do that?

> But, again, why would you want to do that? I don't think this is a general issue, so it is not important at all. But for a large tree like you often see in `InspectTree` I might want to color more stuff to make it clearer what indentation level I am on, but I don't usually prefer it that way when writing queries. E.g. (before the update) `InspectTree` like this: and queries like this: instead of:

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(treesitter): use proper query syntax for inspector
